comments.commentBody: Leave the cops alone!? Their job is to PROTECT AND SERVE us! Not kill us.  What if that was your child?
MJ, the problem with what you are saying is that Mr. Pistorius apologized for killing her --- not for murdering her.   He never admitted what he did.

In California, where I practice criminal defense law, the minimum sentence for a murder conviction as a practical matter is a life sentence. The court can, under limited circumstances, theoretically grant probation, but in a case involving the use of a firearm, even that slim possibility is off the table. It is essentially unheard of for a convicted murderer to not receive a life sentence.

Even criminals know that murder gets you life. I hate to say this, but no wonder South Africa has a huge crime problem. If you could get only six years for killing your girlfriend in California, we would too.

I think it is terribly sad how the court focused on the killer's loss of a good career, and the suffering he has felt. She totally ignored the suffering of the victim's family. This whole thing is a terrible tragedy, and now Mr. Pistorius will soon be back out on the streets, probably in three years. You can do more time in California for a whole long list of crimes, many of them nonviolent.

@dave
It is very plausible that you are right. What I listened to from the case led me to believe that he is a gun nut and his mind when to shoot-first mentality. In our own country it has been found that if you have guns in the house for protection it is more likely you will shoot a family member than a burglar. Maybe I am wrong and maybe he is the best actor in the world, only he would know the full truth.

"This report validates the mistrust people feel towards their political leaders--hello Brexit! Hello Trump."
Baloney! People are voting for Trump to put whites back in power in this country. Nothing more complicated.
This report validates the mistrust people feel towards their political leaders--hello Brexit! Hello Trump.

We **could** drop our cable TV subscriptions especially to the sports channels.  If enough of us did that, there would be no money in the games.  Would it go to teachers?  Not directly, but it might free people up to go out and do something  ( exercise) or learn something -- read, talk to friends, watch PBS.  If we didn't buy into all this cable BS we could  put time and money into something more rewarding than watching millionaires play basketball for billionaires.  We could watch the kid down the block play basketball.  Or even play it ourselves.

Relieved to learn that we are redoubling our efforts to reroute ever more wealth to the NBA so we can be entertained.  Since NASA's budget has been decimated and we can no longer launch an astronaut into space, along with laying off a lot of actual rocket scientists - it's nice to know we are #1 in the world in basketball.  Our sports addicted nation replete with huge coliseums throughout the land gives us much to cheer as our NBA and NFL 'gladiators' battle year round. Our youth wisely look up to these heroes and aspire to follow in their footsteps.  Neil Armstrong is dead.  Long live Lebron James and his well paid journeymen.
Lots of good comments but this one is spot on. Greatest transfer of wealth due to the cable pricing. Municipalities need to get involved and start regulating the cable monopoly.
No one watches the WNBA. One could make the same comment about the men's minor league. Should minor league men make more money even though no one watches their games?

Another great comment. You are correct that corporations buy tickets but the tickets tend to be used by employees and their kids (at least at Timberwolves games). I never see any business being done. This is a very questionable write-off as it is not a business expense. Why should taxpayers support these folks?  Absolutely nuts.

well, thats good bc theyre more important than losers like teachers, who only help prepare your kids for th future

what suckers, huh ?
his say is in not being a fan

ESPN and TNT went overboard on the 24 billion given to the NBA. and why a 180 percent increase in rights fees ? How about 20 percent more. These networks will not make 1 dime over the next 10 years on their NBA broadcasts and cable package. It is a transfer of wealth from the shareholders of those companies. Walt Disney Company and Turner Broadcasting to the NBA and their players. Those networks will most likely regret what they have done as ratings and advertising will not cover this large expenditure.

Congratulations to Curry for handling his salary situation the past 5 years with such integrity and humility!

I just hope the Warriors keep him on and pay him at the top when his contract expires next year! My guess is, they will.

I've lived in Florida although I don't at the moment. What people outside that state don't realize is that northern Florida is the "Deep South," but the southern part is "the North."  Much more cosmopolitan, large NY/NJ retiree population, and, as the article points out, the younger generation of Cuban-descendants are more left-leaning than their parents.  So, while the northern part of the state (the south) is pretty right-wing, the southern part of the state (the north) will likely determine the outcome.  Unusual paradox.  I volunteered for Obama in 2008 in FL and the lean of the southern part of the state was showing at that time.
pretty good Thursday. Got the theme with the SE corner and then the NW corner -- that's amore. liked warts n all  and you don't say. Knew Tessa from the Gondoliers. yeah, Gilbert and Sullivan!

I've never met a rebus I didn't like, but this one was a little simplistic. Just four placements, and all with the same three letters. Also, I thought the revealer, CHECKPOINTS, was lame; it didn't reveal anything, except perhaps that there were places in the puzzle to look at, which is pretty much true of any theme. All that being said, it was a nice, pleasant, rather easy Thursday.

Deb, no need for me to pile on about the Spanish/French mixup.

Purportedly, indeed.

Where are his tax returns?
And why is he avoiding releasing them?

The FRB should consider the appropriate global monetary strategy going forward.

The US economy is relatively healthy and far less impacted by the relative strength of the USD than most nations are to their own domestic currency.

The Fed's mandate of full employment and price stability are met.

Increasingly global central banks have been adjusting monetary policy to each new crisis, using a "beggar-thy-nation" approach of currency depreciation.

With real and nominal rates below 0% in many developed economies, we are in uncharted waters filled with sharks.

First and foremost, interest rates are reducing the cost of production far more than they are stimulating aggregate demand.

One could argue they are undermining aggregate demand through a tax on money and savings, and marginal productive capacity is no longer constrained (by the 0% lower bound) to be in constructive endeavors.

In other words, the central bank is now essentially managing resources by committee through monetary policy measures.

The economy will suffer the fate of all centrally managed economies - underperformance.

Post-Brexit, the BOE and the ECB have their hands tied. The BOJ is dealing with massive unwanted strength in the yen.

If the Fed is to avert a chain of "beggar-thy-neighbor" monetary policies, it must do what only it can do - begin the difficult but necessary process of rate normalization.

Otherwise, the world will sink into a quicksand of negative interest rates.
The Gaul of it all.
There's Java on 7th Av. in Park Slope/Windsor Terrace. And in Elmhurst there are several, the best IMO being Upi Jaya on Woodside Av.

New York City now has a Japanese restaurant on virtually every street corner but decent Indonesian cuisine remains exceptionally hard to come by here.  Not sure why that's the case for one of Asia's most refined and yet most complex cooking styles.  Hopefully Ms. Pratiwi or one of her fellow Indonesian chefs will respond to the call of the famished, make a home in NYC and earn a great deal of money cooking up some rendang or opor ayam.

The economy will suffer the fate of all centrally managed economies - underperformance.

If the Fed is to avert a chain of "beggar-thy-neighbor" monetary policies, it must do what only it can do - begin the difficult but necessary process of rate normalization.

I am 76 years old. My father went all the way through college on free New York City public education. The university of Texas used to be essentially free. I don't recall exactly but somewhere in the 1970s republicans started pressing for tuition at the university and they have been raising it ever since. Those guys always are looking for ways to cut services including education.

Unfortunately, you're unable to do so... 12 million emails were deleted from the RNC server (yes, that's Republican National Committee; your eyes are not deceiving you) from the Bush administration.

President Obama decided the Democratic Party wouldn't pursue "investigations" of the Bush administration, despite glaringly blatantly obvious wrongdoing - "for the good of the country."

Too bad the Republican Party doesn't take the hint.

Uncertainty. Oh no uncertainty! If that's the biggest issue of Brexit then look at quantum physics breakthroughs etc that show uncertainty is a universal constant. Not to mention the uncertainty of how much longer the planet can survive the human race.
